KING COUNTY

DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES

WASTEWATER TREATMENT DIVISION

EPA RISK MANAGEMENT PROGRAM (RMP)



EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



King County's South Treatment Plant (STP) at Renton, Washington is subject to the requirements

stated in Section 112r of the Clean Air Act and 40 CFR Part 68, Chemical Prevention Provisions, known as the

Risk Management Program (RMP).  This RMP executive summary and program submittal describes and details the key elements of the STP Risk Management Program (RMP), as well as the associated Process Safety Management (PSM) program elements.  This document also summarizes our existing health and safety programs; our internal management implementation procedures; emergency response procedures; and ongoing actions that are designed to prevent, eliminate or minimize impacts of accidental releases of digester gas to the environment. The STP is proud of its continuous dedication and commitment to ensuring accident prevention, employee safety and process safety, and as a result the STP has had an excellent record in preventing accidents from occurring.



**In demonstration of the STP's commitment to eliminate or minimize the impacts of potential accidental releases, the STP formally discontinued the use of chlorine gas for disinfection and also discontinued the use of sulfur dioxide gas for the dechlorination.  STP fully decommissioned the facilities and equipment associated with the storage and use of chlorine gas and sulfur dioxide gas.  As a result, the STP has converted to the safer use of sodium hypochlorite for disinfection and sodium bisulfite for dechlorination.**



(1)Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policy:

The STP is totally dedicated and committed to ensuring the prevention of any potential for accidental releases of toxic and flammables materials. The STP accidental release prevention program involves a unified approach that integrates proven technology, state of the art equipment, advanced safety training

programs, staff training on operation and maintenance practices, project management protocols and tested management system practices. All applicable procedures of the State of Washington Department of Labor & Industries, Department of Ecology and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Prevention Program are adhered to, including key elements such as employee training, safety systems management, and emergency response procedures. 



As a result, the STP comprehensively complies with the EPA Risk Management Program under Section 112 (r) of the Clean Air Act (CAA) Amendments of 1990, 40 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Part 68, and the State of Washington Department of Labor & Industries - Division of Occupational Safety and Health - Process Safety Management Program under Washington Administrative Code (WAC) 296-67.



(2)Description of Facility and Regulated Substances

The STP is an integrated sewage treatment facility that provides both primary and secondary treatment of domestic and industrial wastewater prior to discharge to Puget Sound.  The 88-acre site takes in wastewater from 21 pump stations on the east and south sides of Lake Washington, an area of about 140 square miles.  The plant capacity is approximately 70 million gallons of sewage per day.  The treatment plant processes an average of 115 million gallons per day (mgd) wet weather flow and can handle an instantaneous maximum flow of approx. 325 mgd.  Sodium Hypochlorite (a non-covered chemical) disinfects all of the wastewater following treatment before being pumped to Puget Sound.  The digester gas results from the anaerobic biological waste treatment in the secondary treatment system.  The methane from the digester gas is primarily compressed and sold to a commercial gas pipeline system (Puget Sound Energy)for use as domestic natural gas and is also used onsite to fuel a cogeneration and fuel cell facility.  The STP is rated as a US-EPA and WA-DOE Class IV treatment plant.



The liquid tre

atment process includes screening, grit removal, primary clarification, secondary clarification, sodium hypochlorite disinfection, and sodium bisulfite dechlorination. The disinfected effluent discharges to Puget Sound through a multi-port diffuser located offshore in marine waters. 



As for solids treatment, the primary and waste activated solids are blended in a tank and thickened. The thickened sludge is anaerobically digested in a system of digesters, and dewatered by centrifuges. The plant produces biosolids used in agriculture and forestry, reclaimed water used for in-plant processes and irrigation. Digester gas (methane) is also produced and this gas is primarily compressed and sold to a commercial pipeline for use as domestic natural gas and is also used onsite to fuel a cogeneration and fuel cell facility.



The facility complies with all applicable regulations and good engineering practices in the operation of only one process that has a greater than threshold quantity of hazardous chemical (methane/ flammable mixture) as defined in the RMP requirements. This process is the wastewater digester gas (methane/ flammable mixture) system. It is the policy of King County to meet and/or exceed all applicable federal, state, and local laws in the operation of all processes, and to design and operate the systems in accordance with the best industry standards to protect workers, visitors, and the public. 



The STP digester gas was previously considered a system that was eligible for the exclusive fuel exemption, as the digester gas is used exclusively as a fuel for onsite processes or sold to a commercial gas pipeline system (Puget Sound Energy).



However, a joint assessment and interpretation ruling by EPA Region 10 and the State of Washington Department of Labor & Industries, interpreted that the digester gas system's recirculation of digester gas is considered a "process use" and therefore is not eligible for exemption from the RMP regulation.

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

The general accidental release prevention program includes the following key program elements;

*Risk Management Plan - comprehensive plan for preventing the accidental release of hazardous chemicals.

*STP PSM/ RMP Program Manual -  comprehensive manual to centralize safety information and better ensure existing program elements are being properly implemented at the site. 

*PSM/ RMP Management System - system designed to provide and ensure the consistent implementation of the PSM/RMP program.

*PSM/ RMP Hazard Assessment - program designed to ensure the review and analysis of potential worst-case scenarios, alternate-case scenarios, and five year accident history.

*WTD Employee Safety & Accident Prevention Program - comprehensive program implementing all Safety Management Systems elements directing Safe Work Programs, Policies, Procedures and Training.

*STP PSM/RMP Committee and Sub-committee task force - committee of subject matter experts that oversees the administration and implementation of the comprehensive PSM/ RMP program elements.

*Process Safety Information - information pertaining to the process is accurate and up to date.

*Process Hazards Analysis - formal technical hazard reviews are conducted and updated.

*Operating Procedures - written standard operating procedures are in place and up to date.

*Training - personnel are formally trained for the technical and safety aspects of the jobs they are to perform.

*Mechanical Integrity - written procedures are in place for inspection, testing and maintenance of equipment.

*Management of Change - procedures are in place to review and approve changes to the process.

*Pre-Startup Review - a formal procedure is in place to review changes to the process before startup.

*Compliance Audits - periodic comprehensive reviews of the PSM/ RMP elements for compliance.

*Incident Investigation - incidents with the potential for s

erious consequences are reviewed by a dedicated team.

*Employee Participation - all employees are required to participate in all of the release prevention program elements.

*Safe Work Practices (Hot Work Permit) - special permits, protocols, procedures and programs are in place for all Hot Work, Hazardous Energy Control, Confined Space Entry and Gas Purging operations.

*Contractor Safety - a formal program is in place for the selection and review of contractors.

*Emergency Planning, Response & Recovery - program to ensure the establishment and implementation of the necessary emergency action plans for various potential emergency scenarios



In the event of an accidental PSM/ RMP release, the STP is well practiced and exercised in the implementation of the STP emergency action plans, as well as the notification and coordination with the City of Renton Fire Department, King County Zone 3 Technical Response Teams, the King County Office of Emergency Management and other applicable emergency response agencies.



Chemical-specific prevention steps include staff awareness of the hazardous properties of digester gas, the presence of methane detectors, alarms, pressure relief devices, flame arrestors, Ovation Supervisory Control System and the other redundant safety control systems.

The STP accidental release prevention program is based on the following key elements:

*Commitment to safety by the Wastewater Treatment Division and STP management and staff

*Comprehensive process safety information and technical system information that is readily available to staff, emergency responders, and contractors

*Comprehensive corrective and preventive maintenance program

*Routine shift checklist and process hazard analysis of equipment and procedures with operation and maintenance staff participation and review

*Use of state-of-the-art process and safety equipment

*Use of accurate and effective operating procedures, written with operations and maintenance staff participati

on

*High level of training of operators and maintenance staff

*Implementation of an incident investigation, inspection, and auditing programs by highly qualified and experienced staff



(4) Five-Year Accident History:

The South Treatment Plant (STP) has completed the required updated 5-year accident history review and has not had a reportable accident in the last five years that involved deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations or sheltering in place. Procedures and policies are in place and implemented to properly report, respond, record, investigate and debrief any such future accidents and/or incidents.



(5)STP Emergency Response Plan/ Emergency Action Program:

The STP emergency response plan and emergency action program has continually evolved and has been routinely updated from successful existing programs to assure worker safety at the facility. It is the policy of the King County Department of Natural Resources and Parks, Wastewater Treatment Division to notify the Seattle Fire Department and request they respond to various emergency conditions at the facility. This policy has been discussed and coordinated with the fire department and they are aware of the specific chemicals that exceed threshold quantities.  



(6)Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

The STP is constantly striving develop and implement workplace safety improvements for employees, contractors, collection, conveyance and treatment processes, as well as our surrounding community neighbors. Through the continuous implementation of the PSM/ RMP Program, the STP routinely reviews and pursues process  and program changes to improve the safety of the regulated systems, and the facility as a whole.
